body:
The class name is not an optional argument. If anything, it should behave as if that argument is coerced to a string. So,

``` js
selection.classed(undefined, true);
```

Should be equivalent to:

``` js
selection.classed("undefined", true);
```

Likewise, `null` should be treated as `"null"`.

Currently, trying to pass null or undefined blows up on all browsers because the implementation immediately calls string.trim on the specified class name. Coercing this to a string would fix the crash, but it still wouldn’t do what you are asking. It would be equivalent to:

``` js
selection.classed(className || "undefined", true);
```

I think the if statement is probably what you need here, or you need a suitable fallback class when your class name is undefined. Or you could filter your selection in lieu of an if statement, but that might be silly.

Well, maybe I'm tainted too much by jQuery here, but I really like the way it's API allows you to hand data through without a lot of ifs around the calls and get sane results.

In our case, we're building some library code and would like to allow users to attach custom classes to d3 objects. Now of course we can litter the code with if statements to handle missing input, but the classed() call itself is the much more logical place to handle this issue and spare all the replication.

I hope that explains the angle I'm coming from.

Handling the empty string as a NOP could also alleviate this problem quite a bit as it would at least allow code of this form:

```
selection.classed(className || "", true);
```

Which is at least shorter even though it doesn't solve the problem that you always have to remember to check the input to that function.

Using nonstandard string coercion would be surprising. The value `undefined` is coerced to `"undefined"` and the value `null` is coerced to `"null"`. Consider this:

``` js
document.body.setAttribute(undefined, "42");
document.body.setAttribute(null, "bar");
```

Results in:

``` html
<body undefined="42" null="bar">
```

Now, it is true that D3 special-cases null (and undefined) _values_ to remove the attribute, because I wanted a single method that could both add and remove attributes. So D3 isn’t trying to mimic this behavior:

``` js
document.body.setAttribute("foo", null);
```

Which results in:

``` html
<body foo="null">
```

But, removing an attribute is functionality (it changes the DOM), where as doing nothing is a noop. So it feels wrong to special case a null or undefined class list here.

That said, since selection.classed does allow multiple class names (e.g., `selection.classed("foo bar", true)`), I do think it makes sense to allow the empty string as a noop. I’ll file that as a separate bug.

issue.title: selection.classed("", true) should be a noop (not an error).

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

body:
I am very knew to this project, and very new to this type of coding, so if this is a total ignoramus type question, please excuse the learning curve as taken on.  I am versed in cloning base classes, and a number of other items, but as a ms developer, much of this is new.

My question comes from a state of security of not having a base class defined, at least in a minimal sense so'as malicious code cannot be implanted into it. 
Do you find this to be true also in this sense? or the possibility of it, or should I go read up more? :)

@eossipov, I'm not sure I am following you, but I do not see any security implications here. This is not about classes in the JS "object" model, but simply a question of adding CSS classes (strings) to the classList of dom elements.

Sorry, I don't understood your question

Date: Wed, 5 Feb 2014 04:52:59 -0800
From: notifications@github.com
To: d3@noreply.github.com
Subject: Re: [d3] Coerce name argument to selection.classed to a string? (#1625)

@eossipov, I'm not sure I am following you, but I do not see any security implications here. This is not about classes in the JS "object" model, but simply a question of adding CSS classes (strings) to the classList of dom elements.

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I'm sorry I thought you were extending a base class. Guess I should have gone through everything instead of just reading above, I was gone from prog. for over 3 years, and css took the largest jump of all.
